channel.title: Anyone

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

The tic-tac-toe idea is sound!

What the hell is the point of starting a project you know you can already do? The point is that everytime you come to a hurdle, or challenge, you then look how to overcome it and learn through that.

You should follow his advice OP.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

When people ask this question, I always suggest to make a calculator. Then adding a conversion feature to it (Length, Temperature, Volume, Mass, etc)

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

theres no point making a project for learning that you can already do

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“xpatx, post:11, topic:415895”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=517838.msg3762172#msg3762172 date=1316962954]

If you are going to learn robotics/droids programming, you could always try to make some sort of AI.
If you want something easy, make an AI to play tick-tack-toe where it has to think, and not just using pre-given moves.

I don’t know what assignments a teacher would give, so it might be too easy.

I don’t think I have the ability to do a tic-tac-toe that has the ability to out think the user. :[

The point is to make your abilities grow.
[/quote]

You can’t just jump into a giant project, you need to take baby-steps and work your way up. I don’t think that would be a project for me yet, maybe a goal in the future, but not now. I need something easy, but something challenging.[/quote]
If you have learnt some use of graphics in Java you could make a simple paint program. Or even simpler you can implement a simple sort algorithm.
PS: I didn’t see that as a giant project, sorry.

But an easy project with some size is good, as you build it up in baby steps.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

sppt:

I would recommend starting a (simple) project, and learn-as-you-go, it works the best for me.

That’s the issue though, I don’t know what to attempt to create. If someone were to give me an assignment as if you were a teacher, I’d try my best and ask questions. But, on the top of my head I cannot think of what I can actually do and cannot do, because I don’t know my limitations yet. :3 If you want, you can PM me an assignment type of thing haha? :3

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

Theres still alot more basics that you need to learn and if you don’t have a solid foundation of the basics your gonna be screwed. I took AP Computer Science 1 and we didnt even get into polymorphisim, inheritance, error handling, swing until java II in college.

I’m in high school taking AP Computer Science. I don’t think we go into that complex of programming, but I rather someone teach me via Skype or something relevant to that. I’m one of those people who get bored when they read tutorials over and over again trying to figure out the material, for me personally I think it’s easier to watch a video or someone explain it over Skype/ventrillo/etc. Also, yeah I know I didn’t learn enough yet, but I want someone to help me learn so I won’t be screwed in school. I want to be one step ahead, :3

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

Well, basically, in my school I am taking AP Computer Science. In this course we are suppose to learn:

  • Java [I don’t know how far in-depth though]
  • Python (basics)
  • Robotics/droid applications (using a GUI that uses Java I think?)

I feel as if I can use some tutoring from someone in this community. Basically all we have done in the past week is input a data value, it goes into a certain method, then prints it out.

Example:

[CODE]
import java.util.Scanner;

public class convertTemp {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	
	double faren = 0, celc = 0;
	Scanner c = new Scanner(System.in);
	
	System.out.println("Enter the desired Farenheit to be converted:");
	faren = c.nextDouble();
	celc = (faren - 32) / 1.8;
	System.out.println("Celcius: " + celc);

}

}[/CODE]

Now, basically I find this crap easy and simple. Is there ANYONE generous enough to offer me tutorials over skype or msn talk or something? I don’t find reading tutorials easy, I find it if you explain the best you can while conversing, it becomes rather easier to me.

I want to learn something complicated, but something not to complicated. If anyone is generous to do this offer, PM me on here or add my msn: patricknogaj@hotmail.com

Thank you ^^

Read full topic
